name: Delphi
description: Sacred sanctuary of Apollo and seat of the famous Oracle, Delphi sat at the crossroads of ancient Greek and later Roman road networks. The Romans maintained the sanctuary and its road connections after conquering Greece in 146 BCE.

name: Via Appia at Minturnae
description: Preserved basalt paving stones of the Via Appia at the ancient colony of Minturnae, where the road crossed the Liris River on its way south to Capua.

name: Pont du Gard
description: Roman aqueduct bridge in southern Gaul, part of the road infrastructure network supporting the Via Domitia. Built in the 1st century CE, it stands as the highest surviving Roman aqueduct.

name: Porta Nigra, Trier
description: The Black Gate of Augusta Treverorum (modern Trier), a massive Roman city gate built c. 170 CE. It marks the northern terminus of one of the empire's key road corridors through Gaul.
